At Desalpur houses built next to walls have been found. Chanhudaro is located on the bank of the Indus River in Sindh, Pakistan. Bead makers’ shops have been found here.

NOTE: Reference to question came from the news of Sohgaura copper plate inscription found in 2018-19.

questions.question: In which of the following relief sculpture inscriptions is ‘Ranyo Ashoka’ (King Ashoka) mentioned along with the stone portrait of Ashoka?
questions.explanation:
Sub-Theme: Ashoka and sites (location) of his inscriptions

The correct answer is Option (a): Kanaganahalli is in Gulbarga, Karnataka. In this sculptural depiction, the emperor with his queen and attendants are carved on a slab, with “Ranyo Ashoka” (King Ashoka) mentioned along with the stone portrait of Ashoka.

About Sannati and Kanaganahalli Buddhist Sites:

About 3 kilometres from Sannati lies Kanganahalli, a significant Buddhist site where an old Mahastupa was erected.
It is located in India’s Karnataka on the left bank of the Bhima River in the Chitapur Taluk of the Kalaburagi District.
The remnants of a large stupa, as well as numerous brick buildings in the shape of a Chaitya-griha and memorial stupas, were uncovered during excavations conducted at Kanaganahalli from 1994 to 1998.
During the excavations, numerous architectural components of the stupa were discovered, including four pictures of the Buddha, remains of sculptured veneering slabs, pieces of railings, pillars, and The sculptured panels show different Játaka, the legend of Lord Buddha’s life and portraits of numerous Satavahana kings.

questions.question: With reference to forced labour (Vishti) in India during the Gupta period, which one of the following statements is correct?

options.text: It was considered a source of income for the State, a sort of tax paid by the people.
It was totally absent in the Madhya Pradesh and Kathiawar regions of the Gupta Empire.
The forced labourer was entitled to weekly
The eldest son of the labourer was sent as the forced labourer.

questions.explanation:
Sub-Theme: Administrative aspect of Gupta Age

The correct answer is Option (a): During the Gupta period, forced labour (vishti) became a source of income for the state and was also looked upon as a form of taxation on the subjects. Vishti was forced labour in lieu of taxes hence no weekly wages were entitled. Anyone from the family can be sent as a forced labourer, not particularly the eldest son of the family.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements:

In the revenue administration of Delhi Sultanate, the in-charge of revenue collection was known as ‘Amil’.
The Iqta system of Sultans of Delhi was an ancient indigenous institution.
The office of ‘Mir Bakshi’ came into existence during the reign of Khalji Sultans of Delhi.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Sub-Theme: Medieval Terminology or keyword/ Medieval Administration

Statement 1 is correct: In the land revenue system of the Delhi Sultanate, the central government appointed amil to collect revenues in each subdivision called shiq.

Statement 2 is incorrect: The Iqta system of land control was first introduced in the Delhi Sultanate by Iltutmish. The institution known by its Arabic name, iqta, had existed in the early Islamic world as a means of rewarding services to the state. In the administration of the Caliphate, it served as a means of funding operations and compensating civil and military leaders. It was not an ancient indigenous institution.

Statement 3 is incorrect: The office of Mir Bakshi was established under the Mughal empire, who was head of the military department, nobility, information and intelligence agencies.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements:

Saint Nimbarka was a contemporary of Akbar.
Saint Kabir was greatly influenced by Shaikh Ahmad Sirhindi.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Sub-Theme: Bhakti and Sufi Movement

Statement 1 is incorrect: Saint Nimbarka is believed  to  be  the  contemporary  of

Ramanuja(11th  century).  He  believed  in

total devotion to Krishna and Rama. The Mughal emperor Akbar lived from 1542 -1605. Nimbarkacharya also known as Nimbarka, Nimbaditya or Niyamananda, was a Hindu philosopher, theologian and the chief proponent of the theology of Dvaitadvaita (dvaita–advaita) or dualistic–non-dualistic. He wrote Dashasloki and Vedanta. He was also a prominent astronomer

Statement 2 is incorrect: Shaikh Ahmad Sirhindi (1564-1624 AD) was Islami Hanif, scholar of Naqsyabandi silsilah. Kabir (1440-1510 AD) was a follower of Nirguna bhakti of the 15th century.

questions.question:
With reference to Mughal India, what is/are the difference/differences between Jagirdar and Zamindar?

Jagirdars were holders of land assignments in lieu of judicial and police duties, whereas Zamindars were holders of revenue rights without obligation to perform any duty other than revenue collection.
Land assignments to Jagirdars were hereditary and revenue rights or Zamindars were not hereditary.
Select the correct answer using the code given below.
questions.explanation:
Sub-Theme: Mughal Revenue System

Statement 1 is incorrect: Zamindars were also expected to maintain law and order in their jurisdictions. The judicial and police functions were performed locally by zamindars.

Statement 2 is incorrect: Jagirdar only has the right to claim and enjoy the revenue collected from the land. Jagirs were transferable and could be seized too.

Additional information:

The holder of land was termed Zamindar. They have hereditary rights over the land.
The primary responsibility of zamindars was to collect revenue and deposit it in the royal treasury.
Law and order were another duty imposed on zamindars in their jurisdictions. The local zamindars handled the police and judicial duties.
The Jagirdars were the King’s appointed officials who were given land by the King. The jagir system allocated a certain amount of land to each person, without any inheritance rights.
Jagirdar is only entitled to claim and enjoy the revenue collected from the land. Jagirs could be transferred and seized as well.

questions.question: With reference to Mian Tansen, which one of the following statements is not correct?

options.text: Tansen was the title given to him by Emperor Akbar.
Tansen composed Dhrupada on Hindu gods and goddesses.
Tansen composed songs for his patrons.

questions.explanation:
Sub-Theme: Art and Culture during the Mughals

Correct answer is Option (a): Tansen was the title given to him by Raja Vikramjit of

Gwalior.

Raja Ram Chandra of Bandavagarh employed Tansen as a court musician at his darbar (Rewa).
After learning of Tansen’s extraordinary talent, Akbar wrote the king of Rewa a “firman” requesting Tansen and appointed him as one of the Navaratnas in his court.
He bestowed upon him the name “Mian.” According to Lalita Ramakrishna’s Musical Heritage of India, Tansen is also referred to as the “Sangit Samrat”.
He composed various dhrupads on Rama, Parvati, Shiva, and Ganesha. A compilation of 300 of his dhrupad that were in Gauhar Bani is called Kalpadruma. Tansen composed his favorite ragas — Multani, Bhairavi and Todi.
He created the ragas Darbari Kanhra for the night, Mian Ki Todi for the morning, Mian ki Sarang for the midday, and Mian ki Malhar for the season.
His descendants and disciples are called Seniyas. He composed songs for his patrons.

questions.question: Who among the following Mughal Emperors shifted emphasis from illustrated manuscripts to albums and individual portraits?
questions.explanation:
Sub-Theme: Art and Culture during the Mughals

Correct answer is Option (c): Mughal Emperor Jahangir shifted emphasis from illustrated manuscripts  to  albums  and  individual portraits.

The Mughal school of painting achieved increased charm, elegance, and grandeur during his rule.
The portrait of Jahangir, who is pictured holding a picture of the Virgin Mary in his right hand, is the best representation of this time period.
Ayar-i-Danish and Anwar-i-sunavli are two further animal fable books with illustrations that date to Jahangir’s reign.

questions.question: Which among the following is the major dynasty that arose in Deccan and Central India following the decline of the Mauryan empire but before the rise of the Gupta empire?
questions.explanation: The Satavahanas ruled a large part of India from the 1st century BCE to the 3rd century CE, following the Mauryan Empire and preceding the Gupta Empire.

questions.question: With respect to the administration system of the Satavahanas, consider the following pairs: Term - Description: 1. Ahara - Districts 2. Khila - Villages 3. Marudam - Provinces
questions.explanation: "Ahara" referred to districts, while "Khila" referred to uncultivable land during the Gupta period, and "Marudam" referred to ecozones in Sangam literature, not Satavahana provinces.

questions.question: Arrange the following Satavahana Kings chronologically: 1. Vashishtaputra Pulamayi 2. Simuka 3. Gautamiputra Satakarni 4. Hala
questions.explanation: Simuka, the founder, ruled first, followed by Gautamiputra Satakarni, then Vashishtaputra Pulamayi, and finally Hala.

questions.question: Consider the following statements regarding the Satavahana Dynasty: 1. Shaka Kshatrapas were involved in continuous conflict with the Satavahanas over the suzerainty over the Deccan. 2. Satavahanas patronized the Amaravati School of Art.
questions.explanation: Both statements are correct: the Shakas were in conflict with the Satavahanas, and the Satavahanas patronized Amaravati art.

questions.question: This inscription provides intricate details about the reign of Gautamiputra Satakarni, described as the destroyer of the Shakas, Pahlavas, and the Yavanas, as the uprooter of the Kshaharatas and as the restorer of the glory of the Satavahanas.
questions.explanation: The description matches the Nashik inscription, which eulogized Gautamiputra Satakarni’s victories and was written by his mother, Gautami Balashri.

questions.question: With reference to the Satavahana dynasty, consider the following statements: 1. Satavahana kings abolished the varna system in their kingdom. 2. The official language of the Satavahanas was Sanskrit. 3. The Satavahanas assumed the title of Uttarapathapati.
questions.explanation: All statements are incorrect: Satavahanas upheld the varna system, used Prakrit as their official language, and assumed the title Dakshinapathapati, not Uttarapathapati.

questions.question: Which of the following is not correct with respect to the Satavahana dynasty?

options.text: They performed Vedic sacrifices that were discarded by Ashoka.
They are considered the same as the Andhras mentioned in the Puranas.
The material culture of the Deccan under the Satavahanas was solely northern ingredients.

questions.explanation: The material culture of the Satavahanas was a fusion of local elements and northern ingredients, not solely northern.

questions.question: With reference to Satavahana Kings, consider the following statements: 1. Yajna Sri Satakarni is described as khatiya-dapamanamada. 2. Vashishthiputra Pulumayi mostly issued gold coins.
questions.explanation: Both statements are incorrect: Yajna Sri Satakarni was not described as khatiya-dapamanamada; it was Gautamiputra Satkarni. Vashishthiputra Pulumayi issued lead, copper, and bronze coins, not gold.

questions.question: About Satavahana’s family structure, consider the following statements: 1. The Satavahana kings were named after their mother. 2. Satavahanas show traces of a complete matriarchal social structure.

options.text: Both Statement-I and Statement-II are correct and Statement-II is the correct explanation for Statement-I.
Both Statement-I and Statement-II are correct and Statement-II is not the correct explanation for Statement-I.
Statement-I is correct but Statement-II is incorrect.
Statement-I is incorrect but Statement-II is correct.

questions.explanation: The Satavahana kings were named after their mother, but their family structure was patriarchal, not matriarchal.

questions.question: Consider the following statements regarding the Satavahana administration: 1. The Satavahanas retained some administrative structures of Ashokan times and their district was called ahara which was under the officials Amatyas and Mahamatras. 2. Unlike Mauryas, military and feudal traits in the administration were absent in the times of the Satavahanas. 3. The Satavahanas started the practice of granting tax-free villages to Brahmanas and Buddhist monks. 4. The Satavahana kingdom had three grades of feudatories, including Raja, Mahabhoja, and Senapati.
questions.explanation: Statements 1, 3, and 4 are correct. Statement 2 is incorrect because there were military and feudal traits in Satavahana administration.

questions.question: Consider the following statements about crafts and commerce in ancient India: 1. The age of the Shakas, Kushans, Satavahanas (200 BC-AD 250) and the first Tamil states was the most flourishing period in the history of crafts and commerce in ancient India. 2. No excavation indicates that craftsmen inhabited the villages, as they were mostly associated with towns in those times.
questions.explanation: The period of Shakas, Kushans, Satavahanas, and the Tamil states was a flourishing time for crafts and commerce. However, excavations have shown that some craftsmen lived in villages, not just towns.

questions.question: With reference to Post Mauryan crafts and craftsmen, consider the following statements: 1. Uraiyur was a great centre for manufacturing a special type of cloth called shataka. 2. Artisans of this period were organised into guilds which were called shrenis.
questions.explanation: Uraiyur was known for dyeing and textile-related activities, but Mathura was the centre for manufacturing shataka. The guilds, called shrenis, were correctly mentioned.

questions.question: Consider the following statements about the money economy in the Post-Mauryan period: 1. The Indo-Greeks were the first to issue gold coins in India, which increased in number under the Kushans. 2. The Kushans were the first to use the image of Goddess Lakshmi on their coins. 3. Many cities and tribes issued coins roughly between 200 BC and AD 300.
questions.explanation: The Indo-Greeks issued gold coins first, and the Kushans used the image of Goddess Lakshmi. Many cities and tribes issued coins during this period, confirming all statements as correct.

questions.question: Consider the following statements about the crafts and trade in the Post-Mauryan age: 1. Indian glass objects have been found in Afghanistan and Rome. 2. Great advances and specialisations in mining and metallurgy were achieved during this period. 3. Coin-minting was an important craft in the period, and craftsmen used it to make fake Roman coins. 4. Indian iron and steel, including cutlery, were exported to the Abyssinian ports.
questions.explanation: Indian glass was not found in Afghanistan and Rome, but ivories and Roman glass were found in these regions. Mining, metallurgy, and iron exports to Abyssinia were significant achievements during this period. Coin minting, including fake Roman coins, was also common.

questions.question: With reference to Trade routes in ancient India, consider the following statements: 1. Understanding monsoon enabled sailors to sail in much less time from the eastern coast of the Arabian Sea to the western coast ports of Arikamedu and Tamralipti. 2. Uttarapatha was the most frequently used route, connecting Taxila to Ujjain and then to Broach on the western coast.
questions.explanation: The understanding of monsoon did help sailors, but the statement about the monsoon route is not entirely accurate. The Uttarapatha was indeed the most frequently used route.

questions.question: Consider the following articles: 1. Muslin 2. Lead 3. Pearls 4. Wine-amphorae 5. Jewels 6. Precious stones 7. Iron Cutlery Which of the above is/are exported from ancient India to the Roman empire?
questions.explanation: Muslin, pearls, jewels, precious stones, and iron cutlery were exported from India, while lead and wine-amphorae were imported to India.

questions.question: Consider the following statements: 1. The establishment of the Safavid rule in Iran and the neighbouring areas led to the diversion of silk to the Roman Empire through western Indian ports. 2. Roman goods appear in substantial quantities in north India under the Kushana rule. 3. Arretine pottery was regularly found in south, central and western India and Afghanistan during 200 BC–AD 250.
questions.explanation: The statements about Safavid rule, Roman goods in Kushana India, and Arretine pottery in central and western India are not correct.

questions.question: Consider the following statements about the spread of civilization in Orissa during the 1st century BC: 1. Kalinga, or coastal Orissa south of the Mahanadi, rose to importance under Ashoka, though a strong state had been founded in that area in the 1st century BC. 2. The greater part of Orissa, particularly north Orissa, neither experienced state formation nor much commercial activity.
questions.explanation: Both statements are correct. Kalinga became important under Ashoka, and north Orissa lacked state formation and commercial activity due to geographical and political factors.

questions.question: With reference to the cultural and economic development of Orissa during or before the 4th century, consider the following statements: 1. Elements of advanced culture were strictly confined to the coastal belt known as Kalinga and did not spread to any other parts of Orissa. 2. An economic system developed, in which barter was the only method used for large transactions. 3. They had trade connections with the Roman Empire.
questions.explanation: Statement 1 is incorrect as advanced culture spread to other parts of Orissa. Statement 2 is incorrect because metal money was used. Statement 3 is correct with evidence of trade links with the Roman Empire.

questions.question: Consider the following statements about the spread of civilization in Orissa: 1. The Matharas made endowments called agraharas, which consisted of seashells and fish, and were meant to support the recreational activities of the local fishermen. 2. The spread of Sanskrit writing is witnessed in this area.
questions.explanation: Statement 1 is incorrect as agraharas consisted of land and income, not seashells or fish. Statement 2 is correct as Sanskrit writing spread in coastal Orissa from about AD 350 onwards.

questions.question: With reference to the civilization in Bengal regions during the 5th century, consider the following statements: 1. The region situated between the Ganges and the Brahmaputra remained an unsettled and entirely Sanskrit-illiterate region. 2. Land was used for both agricultural and religious purposes. 3. Gold coins called dinara were prevalent among this region.
questions.explanation: Statement 1 is incorrect as the region became settled and Sanskrit-educated. Statements 2 and 3 are correct as land was used for both agricultural and religious purposes, and gold coins were used in land transactions.

questions.question: Consider the following statements regarding Bengali civilization during the middle of the 4th century: 1. People in this area knew Prakrit and professed Buddhism. 2. Sama Haradeva, ruler of Samatata during the 4th century, issued a large number of silver coins in this region.
questions.explanation: Statement 1 is correct as people knew Prakrit and professed Buddhism. Statement 2 is incorrect as Sama Haradeva issued gold coins in the 6th century, not silver coins in the 4th century.

questions.question: Consider the following statements about the fiscal and administrative units of Bengal region during the 7th century: 1. A fiscal and administrative unit called Dandabhukti was formed in the border areas between Bengal and Orissa. 2. Danda means punishment, and Bhukti means enjoyment.
questions.explanation: Both statements are correct. Dandabhukti was a fiscal unit created to pacify the border areas, and despite its name, it had no punitive functions and focused on agricultural development.

questions.question: Consider the following statements about the spread of civilization in Eastern India during the 7th century: 1. There were no well-maintained military camps in eastern India during this time. 2. Land was owned by individual families, but its sale and purchase were subject to the overall control of the local communities. 3. The king was entitled to taxes and also enjoyed rights over waste and fallow land.
questions.explanation: Statement 1 is incorrect as there were well-maintained military camps. Statements 2 and 3 are correct as land was owned by families but regulated by the community, and the king had rights over taxes and fallow land.

questions.question: With reference to civilization in Assam during the 6th-7th century, consider the following statements: 1. The Kamarupa kings adopted the title varman, which means armor and symbolizes a warrior. 2. In the 7th century, Bhaskaravarman emerged as the head of a state which controlled a substantial part of the Brahmaputra basin and some areas beyond it.
questions.explanation: Both statements are correct as the Kamarupa kings adopted the title "varman" and Bhaskaravarman controlled a significant part of the Brahmaputra basin.

questions.question: Which ancient ruler assumed the title 'Sakalottarapathanatha'?
questions.explanation: The title "Sakalottarapathanatha" was used for Harshavardhana, who was a prominent king of the Vardhana dynasty.

questions.question: Which of the following plays was not written by Harshavardhana?
questions.explanation: 'Mrichchakatika' was written by Sudraka, not Harshavardhana. Harsha wrote Nagananda, Priyadarshika, and Ratnavali.

questions.question: Consider the following statements related to Harshavardhana: 1. He forbade the killing of animals for food and implemented harsh penalties for those who violated the law. 2. He organized a gathering at Kannauj in order to pay tribute to the Chinese Buddhist monk Hieun Tsang and disseminate the teachings of Hinayana Buddhism. 3. In his early life, Harsha was a Vaishnaivite and later became an ardent Mahayana Buddhist.
questions.explanation: Statement 1 is correct. Statements 2 and 3 are incorrect as Harsha supported Mahayana Buddhism, not Hinayana, and was initially a Shaivite, not a Vaishnavite.

questions.question: With reference to ancient India, the term ‘Mahasamdhivigrahika’ refers to:

options.text: Officers in charge of food and fodder for the army

questions.explanation: Mahasamdhivigrahika was the foreign minister during Harsha’s reign, managing diplomacy and foreign relations.

questions.question: Which of the following ruler's signature can be found on the Banskhera inscription?
questions.explanation: The Banskhera inscription features the signature of Harshavardhana, with references to the construction of a Shiva temple.

questions.question: With reference to the rule of Pushyabhuti dynasty, consider the statements regarding the position of women: 1. The practice of dowry was not seen during this rule. 2. The practice of sati was banned by the king. 3. Remarriages of widows were not permitted. How many of the above statement(s) is/are not correct?
questions.explanation: The status of women during the Pushyabhuti dynasty worsened. Remarriages of widows were restricted, especially among higher castes. Dowry was already a custom, though not as prevalent, and Sati was practiced, but not as widespread or institutionalized as later.

questions.question: Who among the following was not a contemporary of King Harshavardhana of the Pushyabhuti dynasty?
questions.explanation: Fa-Hien was a Chinese Buddhist monk who visited India during the reign of Chandragupta II in the early 5th century, not during Harsha's time. The other options were contemporaries of Harsha.

questions.question: The title of ‘Asthana Kavi’ in the court of King Harshavardhana belonged to who among the following poets?
questions.explanation: Banabhatta, renowned for composing ‘Harshacharita,’ was titled ‘Asthana Kavi’ in Harsha's court due to his eloquent writing and insightful historical accounts.

questions.question: Consider the following statements regarding Gupta Period: 1. The Allahabad pillar refers to the achievements of Chandragupta II. 2. The Mehrauli iron pillar inscription gives the source for the reign of Samudragupta. Which of the statement(s) given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation: The Allahabad pillar inscription actually refers to the reign of Samudragupta, not Chandragupta II. The Mehrauli iron pillar, with inscriptions of Chandragupta II, does not relate to Samudragupta's reign.

questions.question: Consider the following pairs: King - Title: 1. Chandragupta II - Kaviraja 2. Samudragupta - Mahendraditya 3. Kumaragupta - Vikramaditya How many of the above pair(s) is/are not correctly matched?
questions.explanation: All pairs are incorrectly matched. Chandragupta II is associated with Vikramaditya, Samudragupta with Kaviraja, and Kumaragupta with Mahendraditya.

questions.question: How many of the following is/are the reason for the fall of the Gupta Empire? 1. Huns invasion 2. Rise of feudatories 3. Failure to maintain large army Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
questions.explanation: The fall of the Gupta Empire was due to the Huna invasion, rise of feudatories, and inability to maintain a large army. The empire lost control over various regions, and economic challenges arose.

questions.question: Which Gupta ruler assumed the title ‘Sakari’?
questions.explanation: Chandragupta II assumed the title 'Sakari' after his victory over the Saka satraps, meaning 'destroyer of Sakas'.

questions.question: Chinese traveller Fa-hsien visited India during the reign of:
questions.explanation: Fa-hsien visited India during the reign of Chandragupta II and spent six years in the Gupta Empire.

questions.question: Which of the following source materials help to reconstruct the history of the Gupta period: 1. Puranas 2. Mudrarakshasa 3. Devichandraguptam 4. Allahabad pillar
questions.explanation: Puranas, Mudrarakshasa, Devichandraguptam, and the Allahabad pillar inscription all provide valuable information for reconstructing the Gupta period.

questions.question: Who laid the foundation of Nalanda University?
questions.explanation: Kumaragupta laid the foundation of Nalanda University, a renowned center of learning during the Gupta period.

questions.question: Consider the following statements about Samudragupta’s military campaigns: 1. Samudragupta did not destroy and annex South Indian kingdoms. Instead, he defeated the rulers but gave them back their kingdoms. 2. He only insisted on them to acknowledge his suzerainty.

options.text: Both Statement-I and Statement-II are correct and Statement-II is the correct explanation for Statement-I.
Both Statement-I and Statement-II are correct and Statement-II is not the correct explanation for Statement-I.
Statement-I is correct but Statement-II is incorrect.
Statement-I is incorrect but Statement-II is correct.

questions.explanation: Samudragupta defeated the South Indian rulers but gave back their kingdoms, insisting on their acknowledgment of his suzerainty.

questions.question: With reference to Gupta dynasty, consider the following statements: 1. The political authority was concentrated in the hands of the king in the Gupta administration. 2. They followed the practice of primogeniture in succession. 3. Several offices of administrative posts were combined in the hands of the same person.
questions.explanation: The Gupta administration was decentralized, and the practice of primogeniture was not followed. However, several administrative offices were combined in the hands of the same person.

questions.question: With reference to ancient India, the term ‘Dinaras’ refers to:
questions.explanation: The term "Dinaras" refers to the gold coins issued by the Gupta rulers.

questions.question: In which of the following language 'Prayaga Prashasti’ was composed by Harishena, the court poet of Samudragupta?
questions.explanation: The Prayaga Prashasti, also known as the Allahabad Pillar Inscription, was composed in Sanskrit by Harishena, the court poet of Samudragupta.

questions.question: With reference to administration of Guptas, which one of the following is the correct sequence in descending order in terms of size?
questions.explanation: The kingdom was divided into Bhuktis (provinces), Vishayas (districts), and Vithis (sub-districts).

questions.question: With reference to the ancient Indian history ‘Uparikara’ and ‘Udranga’ were related to:

options.text: Type of taxes collected by ruler

questions.explanation: Uparikara and Udranga were agricultural taxes collected during the Gupta period.

questions.question: With reference to the Bhagavatism which emerged in post-Mauryan times, consider the following statements: 1. Bhagavatism was centred around the worship of Bhagvat or Vishnu and his incarnations. 2. Bhagavatism was marked by bhakti and Vedic rituals and sacrifices. 3. The Gupta rulers gave patronage to Bhagavatism and many of them proclaimed themselves as Bhagavatas. How many of the statement(s) given above is/are not correct?
questions.explanation: Statement 1 and 3 are correct, while Statement 2 is incorrect because Bhagavatism focused on bhakti and non-violence, not Vedic rituals.

questions.question: Consider the following statements: 1. Untouchability was forbidden during the Gupta era due to the exploitative nature of the caste institution. 2. The status of women improved during the Gupta period. Which of the statement(s) given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation: Both statements are incorrect: Untouchability intensified during the Gupta period, and the status of women worsened.

questions.question: Consider the following: 1. Raghuvamsa 2. Kumarasambhava 3. Abhijnanasakuntalam 4. Ritusamhara 5. Malavikagnimitram Which of the above-mentioned works are epics of Kalidasa?
questions.explanation: Kalidasa wrote two major epics: Raghuvamsa and Kumarasambhava. The other works are plays or minor poems.

questions.question: With reference to ancient Indian history, consider the following statements: Art and Architecture during Gupta age Location 1. Sultanganj Buddha Madhya Pradesh 2. Dashavatara temple Bihar 3. Nalanda university Uttar Pradesh How many of the pair(s) given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation: The Sultanganj Buddha is from Bihar, Dashavatara temple is in Deogarh, Uttar Pradesh, and Nalanda university is in Bihar.

questions.question:
With reference to life in the Gupta age, consider the following statements:
1. Civil and criminal laws were clearly defined and demarcated for the first time.
2. The most important officers in the Gupta empire were the Kumaramatyas.
3. Hieun Tsang visited India during the Gupta period.
Which of the statements given above are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct
• The judicial system was far more developed under the Guptas (late 3rd century to mid 6th century)
than in earlier times.
• It was at this period, the civil and criminal laws were clearly defined and demarcated for the first
time.
• Theft and adultery came under criminal laws.
• Disputes regarding various types of properties came under civil law.
Statement 2 is correct
• The Gupta bureaucracy was not as elaborate as that of the Mauryas.
• The most important officers in the Gupta empire were the Kumaramatyas.
• The Kumaramatyas were the high officers and the personal staff of the emperor and were appointed
by the king in the home provinces and possibly paid in cash.
• A link between the central and the provincial administration under the Guptas is furnished by them.
Statement 3 is not correct
• Chinese scholar Hieun Tsang visited during the period of Harshavardhana.
• Chinese traveller Fa-Hien, visited India during the Gupta period.
• He visited many Buddhist sites in what are now Xinjiang, Pakistan, India, Nepal, Bangladesh and Sri Lanka
between 399-412 CE.
• He informed us that Magadha was full of cities and its rich people supported Buddhism and gave charities.
• His writing gives an idea of the economic life of people during the Gupta period.

questions.question: The terms ‘Aprahata’ and ‘Vasti’ in the Gupta period referred to:
questions.explanation:
During the Gupta period, the land was classified as detailed below:
 Kshetra - Cultivable land
 Khila - Waste land
 Aprahata - Jungle or forest land
 Vasti - Habitable land
 Gapata Saraha - Pastoral land
• The Paharpur Copper Plate Inscription indicates that the king was the sole proprietor of the land.
• Even when he made land grants, he reserved his prerogatives over it.
• The location and boundaries of individual plots were marked out and measured by the record keepers
and influential men in the locality.
• As stated in Paharpur plates, an officer called Ustapala maintained records of all the land transactions in
the district and the village accountant preserved records of land in the village.

questions.question:
The Gupta rulers were great patrons of art and literature. How many of the following scholars adorned their court?
1. Aryabhatta
2. Amarasimha
3. Dandin
4. Bhasa
5. Bharavi
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.explanation:
Option 1 and 2 are correct
• Aryabhatta, a renowned mathematician and astronomer, belonged to the Gupta period.
• The Gupta period is unparalleled for its achievements in the field of mathematics and astronomy.
• Aryabhatta wrote Aryabhatiya and Suryasiddhanta.
• In Aryabhatiya, he described the place value of the first nine numbers and the use of zero.
• He calculated the value of Pi and invented algebra.
• In Suryasiddhanta, he proved that the earth revolves around the Sun and rotates on its axis.
• In this way, he discovered the cause of the solar and lunar eclipses and the methods for calculating timings of their occurrence.
• He said that the heavenly bodies, like the moon, were spherical and they are shown by reflecting the light.
• Amarasimha, the Sanskrit grammarian and poet, also flourished during the reign of the Gupta dynasty.
• Chandragupta-II was known for his deep interest in art and culture and nine gems or Navratna adorned
his court. Amarasimha was one among the navratnas.
Options 3, 4 and 5 are not correct
• Dandin, who flourished during the late 6th and early 7th centuries, was an Indian Sanskrit writer of prose
romances and expounder on poetics.
• Dandin adorned the court of the Pallava king Narasimhavarman II.
• He wrote Dashakumaracharita and Avantisundarikatha in Sanskrit.
• Bhasa was a Sanskrit dramatist who predates the Gupta period.
• Estimates of his floruit range from the 4th century BCE to the 4th century CE; the thirteen plays attributed
to him are commonly dated closer to the first or second century CE.
• Bhasa’s influence is seen in the works of the great 5th century dramatist and Gupta contemporary Kalidasa, who consciously imitated and improved upon some of Bhasa’s literary motifs.
• Bharavi, who flourished during 6th century AD, was a Sanskrit poet who was the author of Kiratarjuniya,
one of the classical Sanskrit epics classified as a Mahakavya.
• Bharavi hailed from southern India and flourished during the reigns of king Durvinita of the Western
Ganga dynasty and king Simhavishnu of the Pallava dynasty.

questions.question:
) Consider the following pairs:
 Book Author
1. Mudrarakshasa Sudraka
2. Amarakosha Vishakhadatta
3. Meghaduta Kalidasa
4. Kiratarjuniya Bharavi
How many pair(s) given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Pair 1 is not correct
• Vishakhadatta's Mudrarakshasa is a classical Sanskrit play that vividly dramatizes the political intrigue
and machinations surrounding the establishment of the Mauryan empire in ancient India.
• Written between the 4th and 8th centuries CE, the play centers on the astute strategies employed by
Chanakya (Kautilya) to secure Chandragupta Maurya's ascendancy to power.
• Bhasa was an important poet in the early phase of the Gupta period and he wrote 13 plays.
• He wrote in Sanskrit, but his dramas also contain a substantial amount of Prakrit.
• He was the author of a drama called Daridracharudatta, which was later re-fashioned as Mrichchhakatika or the Little Clay Cart by Shudraka.
• The play deals with the love affair of a poor Brahmana trader with a beautiful courtesan and is considered
one of the best works of ancient drama.
Pair 2 is not correct
• The Gupta period also saw the development of Sanskrit grammar, based on the works of Panini and
Patanjali.
• This period is particularly memorable for the compilation of Amarakosha by Amarasimha, who was a
luminary in the court of Chandragupta II.
• Most of his work was destroyed with the exception of the AmaraKosha.
• The Amarakosha is a vocabulary of Sanskrit roots, in three books, and hence sometimes called Trikanda
or the Tripartite.
Pair 3 is correct
• Kalidasa, the greatest poet of the Gupta period, lived in the 4th century AD and was a contemporary of
Chandragupta II.
• Ritusamhara was his first production, although his earliest drama was Malvikagnimitram.
• Meghaduta is a pioneer of Dutakavya in Sanskrit literature.
 Meghaduta refers to a cloud messenger. It is a poem woven around a Yaksha, a subject of Lord
Kubera.
 It tells the story of a yaksa (or nature spirit) who was banished by his master to a far away place for
a year and begged a cloud to deliver a message of love to his wife.
Pair 4 is correct
• Bharavi is well-known for Kiratarjuniya, composed around 550 CE.
• Kirat is Shiva, who speaks to Arjuna as a mountain dwelling hunter.
• This epic style kavya is considered one the greatest works in Sanskrit, celebrated for the complexity of
the language.

questions.question:
Which of the following statement(s) is/are correct about the plays of the Gupta
period?
1. They are all comedies and there are no tragedies in these plays.
2. The Shudras in these plays spoke Sanskrit language like the higher classes.
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct
• The Gupta period was bright in the history of classical literature.
• During the Gupta period, more emphasis was placed on verse than prose.
• Sanskrit was the official language of the Gupta period.
• Although much Brahmanical religious literature was produced during the period, it is also remarkable for
the rise of secular literature consisting of a fair degree of court poetry.
• The Gupta rule between 300 and 600 CE is termed the golden age of India for the development of
science and emphasis on Indian art and literature.
• This era witnessed the compilation of an extensive range of both religious and secular texts.
• Major epics, such as the Ramayana and the Mahabharata, were finalized during the fourth century, embodying good prevailing over evil themes.
• The plays produced in India during the Gupta period have two common features.
• First, they are all comedies; no tragedies are found and they end with a positive note.
Statement 2 is not correct
• Secondly, the characters of the higher and the lower classes do not speak the same language.
• In a Sanskrit drama, the characters of higher castes, such as kings, ministers, etc., speak the Sanskrit language.
• In contrast, the characters of the lower caste, like Shudras and women (including queens), speak in Prakrit.

questions.question: With reference to ancient Indian history, the term ‘niyoga’ denoted:

options.text: Consequences one had to face in the next life because of their past life actions.
A practice in Jainism involving self-reflection, repentance, and seeking forgiveness for past transgressions.
Predetermined course of events and fate in a person's life.
A practice where a younger brother or close relative marries the widow of the deceased elder brothe

questions.explanation:
Niyoga, an ancient Indian practice, allowed a widow to marry a close relative, usually a younger brother
or kinsman, after her husband's death.
• It was practised by the Brahmanas and Kshatriyas in Vedic times, but was not allowed to them by the
law-books of Gupta and earlier times.
• This custom aimed to ensure the continuation of the family line and fulfill the obligation of producing an
heir.
• Niyoga held cultural and familial importance, emphasizing the significance of lineage and responsibilities
within the society of that era.
• Karma: Consequences one had to face in the next life because of their past life actions.
• Pratikramana: A practice in Jainism involving self reflection, repentance, and seeking forgiveness for past
transgressions.
• Niyati: Predetermined course of events and fate in a person's life

questions.question:
Consider the following statements regarding Gupta Empire:
1. The Gupta ruler entered into matrimonial alliance with the Vakataka dynasty of the Deccan.
2. In general, women did not have the autonomy to independently access land resources.
3. Some of the Brahmanas were exempted from paying land revenue.
How many of the statement(s) given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct
• Prabhavati Gupta was the daughter of one of the most important rulers in early Indian history, Chandragupta II (375-415 CE).
• She was married into another important ruling family, that of the Vakatakas, who were powerful in the
Deccan.
• The Vakataka dynasty rose to prominence in the 3rd century CE under the leadership of its first known
ruler, Vindhyashakti.
• They were the most important successors of the Satavahanas in the Deccan and coexistent with the Guptas in northern India.
• The Vakataka dynasty, although relatively short-lived, played a significant role in the cultural and architectural history of India.
• Their patronage of cave temples and their support for both Hinduism and Buddhism left a lasting legacy
in the Deccan region.
• The exquisite cave paintings and sculptures in the Ajanta, Ellora, and Elephanta caves are a testament
to their contributions to Indian art and culture.
Statement 2 is correct
• Sanskrit legal texts, for instance, typically did not grant women independent access to resources like
land.
• However, it's worth noting that exceptions existed, as seen in the case of Queen Prabhavati, who had
access to and could grant land, which was somewhat unusual for her time.
Statement 3 is correct
• There were regional variations in the sizes of land donated ranging from small plots to vast stretches of
uncultivated land and the rights given to the recipients of the grant.
• An agrahara was land granted to a Brahmana, who was usually exempted from paying land revenue
and other dues to the king, and was often given the right to collect these dues from the local people.

questions.question:
With reference to the Gupta period, which one of the following statements is
correct?

options.text: The Guptas issued the largest number of gold coins but coins made of silver were very rare.
During this period, the position of Shudras improved, and there was a decline in Brahmanical supremacy

Widow re-marriage was not allowed to members of the higher social orders but the Shudras could
practice levirate and widow remarriage.
Buddhism continued to receive high royal patronage during the Gupta period

questions.explanation:
Statement (a) is not correct
• In ancient India, the Guptas issued the largest number of gold coins, which were called dinaras in their
inscriptions.
• After conquering Gujarat, the Guptas also issued numerous silver coins for local exchanges, emphasizing the prominence of silver during the Western Kshatrapas rule.
• In contrast, Gupta copper coins were relatively scarce in number compared to those of the Kushanas.
Statement (b) is not correct
• Large-scale land grants to the brahmanas suggest that the brahmana supremacy increased in Gupta
times.
• The brahmanas accumulated wealth on account of the numerous land grants made to them and therefore
claimed many privileges, which are listed in the Narada Smriti, the lawbook of Narada, a work of about
the fifth century.
• The position of Shudras improved during this period.
• They were now permitted to listen to recitations of the Ramayana, the Mahabharata, and the Puranas.
• The Shudras could also worship a new god called Krishna and were also permitted to perform certain
domestic rites which naturally meant fees for the priests.
Statement (c) is correct
• In ancient Vedic times, the practice of Niyoga (levirate) allowed younger brothers or kinsmen to marry
the widow of an elder brother after his demise.
• However, during the Gupta period and earlier, this practice was prohibited by the prevailing law-books
for Brahmins and Kshatriyas.
• Likewise, widow remarriage was restricted for higher caste members, but Shudras were allowed to
engage in both levirate and widow remarriage.
Statement (d) is not correct
• Buddhism ceased to receive royal patronage during the Gupta period.
• Fa-Hien gives the impression that this religion was flourishing, but in reality, it was not as important
during the Gupta period as it had been in the days of Ashoka and Kanishka.
• However, some stupas and viharas were constructed, and Nalanda became a center of Buddhist education.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is not correct about Chalukya King Pulakeshin-II?

options.text: He is known to us from the eulogy written on him by the court poet Ravikirti in the Aihole inscription.
He defeated Harsha’s army on the Narmada and checked his advance towards the Deccan.
He killed the Pallava king Narasimhavarman, who occupied the Chalukya capital at Vatapi.

He conquered the Kadamba capital at Banavasi and forced the Gangas of Mysore to recognize his
authority.

questions.explanation:
There are many important events during the reign of “Pulakeshin-II” (AD 609–42), the most famous
Chalukya king.
Statement (a) is correct
• He is known to us from the eulogy written on him by the court poet Ravikirti in the Aihole inscription
and this inscription is an example of the poetic excellence achieved in Sanskrit, and despite its exaggeration is a valuable source for the life of Pulakeshin.
Statement (d) is correct
• He subjugated the Kadamba capital at Banavasi and compelled the Gangas of Mysore to
acknowledge his suzerainty.
Statement (b) is correct
• He also defeated Harsha’s army on the Narmada and checked his advance towards the Deccan.
Statement (c) is not correct
• In his conflict with the Pallavas, he almost reached the Pallava capital, but the Pallavas purchased peace
by ceding their northern provinces to Pulakeshin-II.
• Around AD 610 Pulakeshin-II also conquered the entire area between Krishna and the Godavari, which
came to be known as the province of Vengi. Here, a branch of the main dynasty was set up and is known
as the eastern Chalukyas of Vengi.
• Pulakeshin’s second invasion of Pallava territory ended in failure.
• The Pallava king “Narasimhavarman”(AD 630–68) occupied the Chalukya capital at Vatapi in about AD
642, when Pulakesin-II was probably killed in a battle against the Pallavas.
• Narasimhavarman assumed the title of Vatapikonda or the conqueror of Vatapi.

questions.question:
Consider the following dynasties:
1. Pallavas of Kanchi
2. Cheras
3. Chalukyas of Badami
4. Pandyas of Madurai
5. Satavahanas
How many of the above dynasties established their kingdoms in the period between 300 and 750 CE?
questions.explanation:
The period from c. 300−750 CE marks the second historical phase in the region south of the Vindhyas.
• The three major kingdoms of this era were the Pallavas of Kanchi, the Chalukyas of Badami, the
Pandyas of Madurai.
• Trade, towns and coinage declined in this phase. However, there was more expansion of the agrarian
economy.
• There was more emphasis on Brahmanism and more instances of Vedic sacrifices by kings.
• The culture of Megaliths paved the way for temple construction.
• Sanskrit became the official language of the peninsula and most charters were prepared.
Option 1 is correct
• On the ruins of the Satavahanas, in the eastern part of the peninsula (especially in the Krishna−Guntur
region), arose the Ikshvakus.
• The Ikshvakus were supplanted by the Pallavas.
• The term Pallava means ‘creeper’, which is a Sanskrit version of the word tondi and in Tamil they are
synonymous to robber.
• So, the Pallavas were probably a pastoral local tribe who established their authority in the land of
creepers called Tondaimandalam (the land between the north Penner and north Vellar rivers), mostly
comprising southern Andhra Pradesh and northern Tamil Nadu with their capital at Kanchi.
• Kanchi (modern Kanchipuram), under them, became an important temple town and a centre of trade
and commerce.
• Some inscriptions refer to early kings of this dynasty, such as Shivaskandavarman, who probably ruled
in the early 4th century CE.
• But in the last quarter of the 6th century, Simhavishnu was the ruler who played a crucial role in the
Pallavas’ rise to power.
Option 3 is correct
• The Vakatakas were followed by the Chalukyas of Badami, who played a prominent role in the history
of Deccan and south India for about two hundred years from the beginning of the 6th century CE.
• The Chalukyas were a maritime power, and they set up their kingdom in western Deccan with the capital
at Vatapi (modern Badami in Karnataka).
• Along with the Chalukyas of Badami (who are primarily called the Western Chalukyas), there were two
other branches of the lineage who ruled independently — the Eastern Chalukyas of Vengi and the
Chalukyas of Lata.
• The Western Chalukyas, in order to acquire legitimacy and respectability, claimed Brahmanical origin as
Haritiputras of the Manavya gotra.
Option 4 correct
• The Pandyas were involved in internecine wars with the other contemporary powers such as the Pallavas.
• They were in control of Madurai and Tirunelveli district of Tamil Nadu.
• There is not enough information about the Pandyas of the early medieval times.
Options 2 and 5 are not correct
• The first historical Phase in southern India belongs to c. 200 BCE−300 CE
• The major kingdoms were the Satavahanas, the Cholas, the Cheras, and the Pandyas.
• This period was marked by the appearance of numerous crafts, internal and external trade, widespread
use of coins and a good number of towns.
• This period offered patronage to Buddhism as is evident in extensive Buddhist monuments in both
Andhra and Maharashtra.
• The Cave inscriptions also point to the existence of Jainism and Buddhism in the southern districts of
Tamil Nadu.
• The epigraphs were mostly written in Prakrit.

questions.question:
With reference to South India in the period between 300−750 CE, consider the
following statements
1. Narasimhavarman founded the port city of Mahabalipuram or Mamallapuram in the seventh century.
2. Pattadakal has ten temples built in the seventh and eighth centuries, the most celebrated of which
are the Kailasanatha temple and the Shore temple.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct
• The Pallava kings constructed a number of stone temples in the seventh and eighth centuries.
• The most famous of them are the seven ratha temples at Mahabalipuram, at a distance of 65 km from
Chennai.
• These were built in the seventh century by Narasimhavarman, who founded the port city of Mahabalipuram or Mamallapuram.
• This city is also famous for the Shore Temple, which was a structural construction erected independently.
• In addition, the Pallavas constructed several such structural temples at their capital Kanchi.
Statement 2 is not correct
• The Chalukyas of Badami erected numerous temples at Aihole, which has as many as seventy, from
about AD 610.
• The work was continued in the adjacent towns of Badami and Pattadakal.
• Pattadakal has ten temples built in the seventh and eighth centuries, the most celebrated of which
are the Papanatha temple and the Virupaksha temple.
• The first of these, although 30 m long, has a low and stunted tower in the northern style; the second was
constructed in purely southern style.
• After the eighth century, land grants to temples became a common practice in south India, and usually
they were recorded on the walls of the temples.
• Most temples were managed by the brahmanas.
• By early medieval times, such temples came to own three-fifths of the arable land, and became centres
of religious rituals and caste based ideology in south India.
• However, the earlier temples seem to have been constructed and maintained out of the taxes directly
collected by the king from the common people.
• Some temples in Karnataka under the Chalukyas were erected by Jaina traders.
• Kailasanath temple is one of the largest Indian megalith temples located in the Ellora, Maharashtra.
• It is said to be constructed by Rashtrakuta king Krishna I.
• Shore Temple at Mamallapuram is a structural temple, built with blocks of granite.
• It was built during the reign of Narasimhavarman II of the Pallava dynasty

questions.question:
Who assumed the title of ‘Vatapikonda, or the Conqueror of Vatapi’ among the
following kings?
questions.explanation:
Narsimhavarman is the Pallava King who ruled South India between 630-668 A.D.
• He got the title of 'Vatapikonda' after defeating the Chalukya King and acquired Badami.
• 'Vatapikonda' means the conqueror of Vatapi.
• Chalukyan Emperor “Pulakeshin II” had previously raided various northern Pallava provinces and forts.
However, he was unable to capture the Pallava capital of Kanchipuram, this led to a long conflict between
the Chalukyas and the Pallavas.
• He avenged his father's defeat at the hands of the Chalukya monarch, Pulakeshin II in the year 642 CE.
• Narasimhavarman-I was also known as Mamallan (great wrestler), and Mamallapuram (Mahabalipuram)
was named in his honour.
• It was during his reign, in 640 CE, that the Chinese traveller Hiuen Tsang visited Kanchipuram

questions.question:
Consider the following statements:
1. The Pallavas, the Kadambas, the Chalukyas of Badami, and their other contemporaries rejected the
Vedic sacrifices.
2. The worship of Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva, especially of the last two, has become popular since the
seventh century in southern India.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is not correct
• The Pallavas, the Kadambas, the Chalukyas of Badami, and their other contemporaries were great
champions of Vedic sacrifices.
• They performed ashvamedha and vajapeya sacrifices, which legitimized their position, enhanced their
prestige, and enormously increased the income of the priestly class.
• The brahmanas therefore emerged as an important class at the expense of the peasantry, from whom
they collected their dues directly.
• They also received as gifts a substantial proportion of the taxes collected by the king from his subjects.
Statement 2 is correct
• Besides the performance of Vedic sacrifices, the worship of Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva, especially of
the last two, was becoming popular.
• From the seventh century onwards, the Alvar saints, who were great devotees of Vishnu, popularized
the worship of this god.
• The Nayanars rendered a similar service to the cult of Shiva.
• From the seventh century onwards, the cult of bhakti began to dominate the religious life of south
Indians, and the Alvars and Nayanars played a great part in propagating it.

questions.question:
With reference to the western Ganga dynasty, consider the following statements:
1. Western Gangas is an important contemporary dynasty of the Pallavas.
2. They established their kingdom in southern Kerala around the fourth century.
3. Their earliest capital was located at Kolar which, given its gold mines, may have helped the rise of this
dynasty.
How many of the above statement(s) is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct
• Western Gangas were an important contemporary dynasty of the Pallavas.
• They are called the Western Gangas or Gangas of Mysore in order to differentiate them from the Eastern Gangas who ruled in Kalinga from the fifth century onwards.
• For most of their reign, the Western Gangas were feudatories of the Pallavas.
Statement 2 is not correct
• They established their kingdom in southern Karnataka around the fourth century.
• The kingdom was situated between that of the Pallavas in the east and of the Kadambas in the west.
Statement 3 is correct
• Their earliest capital was located at Kolar which, given its gold mines, may have helped the rise of this
dynasty.
• The Western Gangas made land grants mostly to the Jainas.

questions.question:
) With reference to the dynasties of southern India from 600-750 CE, consider the
following pairs:
 Dynasty Location
1. Western Chalukyas
Madurai
2. Pandyas Badami
3. Western Gangas
Mysore
4. Kadambas Banavasi
How many of the pair(s) given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Pair 1 is not correct
• In northern Maharashtra and Vidarbha (Berar), the Satavahanas were succeeded by the Vakatakas.
• The Vakatakas were followed by the Chalukyas of Badami, who played a prominent role in the history
of Deccan and south India for about two hundred years from the beginning of the 6th century CE.
• The Chalukyas were a maritime power and they set up their kingdom in western Deccan with the capital
at Vatapi (modern Badami in Karnataka).
• Along with the Chalukyas of Badami (who are primarily called the Western Chalukyas), there were two
other branches of the lineage who ruled independently, the Eastern Chalukyas of Vengi and the Chalukyas of Lata.
• The Western Chalukyas, in order to acquire egitimacy and respectability, claimed Brahmanical origin
as Haritiputras of the Manavya gotra.
• The founder, Pulakesin I (543-66 CE) converted the hill near Badami into a strong fortress and launched
his expansionist activities.
Pair 2 is not correct
• By the beginning of the seventh century, the Pallavas of Kanchi, the Chalukyas of Badami, and the
Pandyas of Madurai emerged as the rulers of the three major states.
• The Pandyas were involved in internecine wars with the other contemporary powers such as the Pallavas.
• They were in control of Madurai and Tirunelveli district of Tamil Nadu.
• There is not enough information about the Pandyas of the early medieval times.
Pair 3 is correct
• Western Gangas were an important contemporary dynasty of the Pallavas.
• They are called the Western Gangas or Gangas of Mysore in order to differentiate them from the Eastern Gangas who ruled in Kalinga from the fifth century onwards.
• For most of their reign, the Western Gangas were feudatories of the Pallavas.
• They established their kingdom in southern Karnataka around the fourth century.
• The kingdom was situated between that of the Pallavas in the east and of the Kadambas in the west.
• Their earliest capital was located at Kolar which, given its gold mines, may have helped the rise of this
dynasty.
Pair 4 is correct
• Since the 4th century CE, the Kadambas had ruled over northern Karnataka and Konkan.
• They had their capital at Vaijayanti or Banavasi in north Kanara district in Karnataka.
• They were contemporaries of the Pallavas and claimed to be Brahmanas.
• They also generously gifted a lot to the Brahmanas.
• The Kadamba dynasty was founded by Mayurasharman, who defeated the Pallavas with the help of
forest tribes.

questions.question:
With reference to the Kalabhra Revolt of 6th century, Consider the following
statements ;                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  1. The Kalabhra revolt was a powerful peasant protest directed against the landed brahmanas.
2. The Kalabhras were patrons of Buddhism.
3. By the last quarter of the 6th century, the Kalabhras had imprisoned the Chola, the Pandya, and the
Chera kings.
How many of the above statement(s) is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct
• Although the period between AD 300 and 750 was extremely important for state formation and agrarian expansion in the peninsula, very little is known about what happened at the tip of the peninsula after
the eclipse of the Cholas, the Cheras, and the Pandyas.
• The only important event is a revolt led by the Kalabhras in the sixth century.
• The Kalabhras seem to have been a tribal people who captured power, particularly at the cost of the
Cholas, and ruled for seventy five years.
• Their rule also affected the Pallavas as well as their neighbouring contemporaries.
• The Kalabhras are called evil rulers, who overthrew innumerable kings and established their hold on the
Tamil land.
• The Kalabhra revolt was a powerful peasant protest directed against the landed brahmanas.
• The repeated teaching that those who attack land grants are condemned to hell for sixty thousand years
failed to change their minds.
• They put an end to the brahmadeya rights granted to the brahmanas in numerous villages.
Statement 2 is correct
• It appears that the Kalabhras were of Buddhist persuasion as they patronized Buddhist monasteries.
• The Kalabhras’ revolt was so widespread that it could be quelled only through the joint efforts of the
Pandyas, the Pallavas, and the Chalukyas of Badami.
Statement 3 is correct
• By the last quarter of the sixth century, according to a tradition, the Kalabhras had imprisoned the
Chola, the Pandya, and the Chera kings, which underlines how formidable their revolt was.
• The confederacy of the kings formed against the Kalabhras, who had revoked the land grants made
to the brahmanas, shows that the revolt was directed against the existing social and political order in
south India.

questions.question:
Consider the following pairs:
 Emblem Kingdom
1. Fish Pandyas
2. Varaha Cholas
3. Bow Cheras
How many of the above pair(s) is/are correctly matched?
questions.explanation:
The emblems of ancient Indian kingdoms are significant symbols that reflect the identity, culture, and
heritage of these dynasties.
• The Pandya, Chola, and Chera dynasties, among the prominent rulers in South Indian history, each had
unique emblems that were used in coins, inscriptions, and various forms of art and architecture.
• These symbols not only served as markers of the dynasty's sovereignty and influence but also played a
crucial role in their historical narratives.
Pair 1 is correct
• The Pandya dynasty, one of the ancient Tamil dynasties in southern India, is known to have used the fish
as their emblem.
• This symbol is often depicted as two fish.
• The fish symbol appears on various Pandya coins, inscriptions, and seals. Historical texts and records,
including Tamil literature like the Sangam texts, also refer to the fish as a symbol of the Pandya kings.
Pair 2 is not correct
• The Chola dynasty, another prominent Tamil dynasty, is not associated with the varaha (boar) symbol.
• Instead, the Cholas are known for their emblem of the tiger.
• Numerous Chola coins, inscriptions, and temple murals feature the tiger symbol prominently.
• The Chola emblem can be seen on the coins issued during the reign of Rajaraja Chola I and Rajendra
Chola I, which feature the tiger, sometimes accompanied by a fish and a bow, indicating their conquests
over the Pandya and Chera territories.
• The varaha or boar symbol is most closely associated with the Western Chalukya dynasty, reflecting
their cultural and religious ethos during their rule in southern and central India.
Pair 3 is correct
• The Chera dynasty, another ancient Tamil dynasty, is historically associated with the bow as their emblem.
• The Cheras ruled parts of present-day Kerala and Tamil Nadu.

questions.question:
With reference to the Guptas, consider the following statements:
1. Coins were struck in the joint names of Chandragupta II, his queen and the Lichchhavi nation, acknowledging their marital alliance.
2. Charles Wilkins called Samudragupta as the ‘Napoleon’ of India.
3. The Buddhist philosopher Vasubandhu was a contemporary of Guptas.
How many of the above statement(s) is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is not correct
• Chandragupta I (not Chandragupta II) married a Lichchhavi princess named Kumaradevi.
• This alliance was significant for the Gupta empire, and there were coins that commemorate this marital
alliance.
• These coins feature the names of Chandragupta I and Kumaradevi, highlighting the importance of this
union and the Lichchhavi lineage.
• Infact, Samudragupta was referred to as Lichchhavi-dauhitra (grandson of Lichchhavis) in the famous
Allahabad Prashasti.
Statement 2 is not correct
• It was Vincent Arthur Smith who called Samudragupta the ‘Napoleon of India’ due to his extensive
military conquests.
• Charles Wilkins is known for translating the Bhagavad Gita into English.
Statement 3 is correct
• Vasubandhu, a significant Buddhist philosopher, is believed to have been a contemporary of the
Gupta period.
• Vasubandhu was one of the ministers of of Samudragupta. Though Samudragupta was a Hindu by practice, he extended his patronage to other religions also

questions.question:
Consider the following statements regarding Sangam literature:
1. All three Sangams received patronage from Pandyan kingdoms.
2. The poets of Sangam were exclusively men from various social classes.
Which of the statement(s) given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
The Sangam Age is a significant phase in the history of ancient South India, spanning roughly from the
3rd century BCE to the 3rd century CE.
• It is also referred to as the period of Tamil Literature.
Statement 1 is correct
• The three Sangams were patronized by Pandya rulers and were known as the Talai Sangam, Idai Sangam, and Kadai Sangam, meaning the beginning, middle, and end Sangams, respectively.
• The Sangam literature can roughly be divided into two groups, narrative and didactic.
• The narrative texts are called Melkannakku or Eighteen Major Works. They comprise eighteen major
works consisting of eight anthologies and ten idylls.
• The didactic works are called Kilkanakku or Eighteen Minor Works.
• Sangam literature is a rich source of information as it describes various activities related to agriculture.
• It includes detailed accounts of secondary production activities, such as making sugar from sugarcane,
and primary agrarian activities, such as cultivating ragi and sugarcane, harvesting grain, and drying grain.
Statement 2 is not correct
• The poets included both men and women from all social classes, and they were richly rewarded for their
compositions.
• Women Poets:
 Avvaiyar: One of the most celebrated women poets of the Sangam age. She is known for her wisdom,
moral teachings, and simple yet profound poetry.
 Aiyai: Another notable woman poet whose works often explore themes of love and separation.
• Royalty and Nobility:
 Neduncheliyan: A Pandya king known for his patronage of arts and literature, he is often mentioned
in the poems for his valour and generosity.
 Koluthungo Chera: A Chera king who was also a poet. His works often praised the valour of his
dynasty and their victories.
• Warriors and Chieftains:
❖ Pisiranthaiyar: A poet and warrior who is known for his friendship with the Pandya king Nedunchezhiyan. His poems reflect loyalty and valour.
❖ Purananuru Poets: Several poets of the Purananuru collection were warriors and chieftains, contributing to the themes of war and heroism.
• Farmers and Agriculturists:
❖ Velliveethiyar: A poetess believed to be from a farming community, her poems in the Sangam corpus
reflect the agrarian lifestyle and the beauty of rural landscapes.
❖ Poet of Neithal Thinai: Several anonymous poets who composed under the Neithal thinai (the
coastal landscape) theme were from fishing and farming communities, depicting their livelihoods
and environment.
• Religious Figures and Philosophers:
❖ Kapilar: In addition to his connection with the merchant class, Kapilar was also considered a philosopher-poet with deep insights into human life and nature.
❖ Sekkizhar: Though belonging to a slightly later period, he was often associated with the tail end of
the Sangam tradition, known for his contributions to Tamil religious literature.
• Commoners:
❖ Mamangam Kanniyar: A poet from a humble background, known for her poignant verses on the
themes of love and separation.
❖ Mudukanniyar: Another poet from the common class whose works capture everyday life and emotions.

questions.question: Which of the following was considered as the “Odyssey of Tamil poetry”?
questions.explanation:
Option (b) is correct
• Manimekalai is one of the five great epics of Tamil literature, written by the Chithalai Chathanar.
• It is considered a sequel to the epic Silappadikaram and continues the story of Kovalan and Madhavi’s
daughter, Manimekalai. Therefore, it is called the Odyssey of Tamil poetry.
• Central to Manimekalai is the concept of karma, which influences the characters' destinies and actions.
• The cycle of birth and rebirth is a recurring theme.
• Manimekalai’s decision to renounce her life as a courtesan and embrace Buddhism highlights the theme
of renunciation of worldly desires for spiritual enlightenment.
Option (a) is not correct
• Silappadikaram is written by Ilango Adigal, a Jain monk and the brother of Chera king Senguttuvan.
• Central to Silappadikaram is the theme of justice.
• Kovalan’s wrongful execution by the Pandya king, based on a false accusation of theft, highlights the
miscarriage of justice.
• Kannagi’s quest for justice for her husband’s death and her ultimate confrontation with the Pandya king
emphasizes the moral responsibility of rulers to ensure justice.
Option (c) is not correct
• The Gita Govinda, a piece of devotional literature composed on the theme of love between Radha
and Krishna, by Jayadeva.
• The text weaves together themes of divine love, separation and union, Bhakti, nature, and spiritual allegory.
Option (d) is not correct
• Nitisara, attributed to Kamandaka, is a seminal text on statecraft and political science in ancient
India.
• It is a comprehensive guide for rulers on governance, diplomacy, military strategy, and ethical conduct.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements regarding the Sangam literature:
1. Tolkappiyam is a treatise on grammar and poetics.
2. Tolkappiyam is the only surviving work from the first Sangam.
3. Silappadikaram, authored by Sittalai Sattanar, offers valuable insights into Sangam polity and society.
How many of the above statement(s) is/are not correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct
• Tolkappiyam is an ancient Tamil text on grammar and poetics.
• It is considered one of the oldest extant works of Tamil literature, dealing with linguistic aspects (phonology, morphology, and syntax) and literary conventions.
Statement 2 is not correct
• While Tolkappiyam is one of the oldest and most significant texts, the claim that it is the only surviving
work from the first Sangam is not accurate.
• The first Sangam (Muchchangam) is said to have been held at Thenmadurai, but none of its works have
survived.
• The second Sangam (Idaichangam) was held at Kapadapuram, and only fragments of the works exist.
• Only Tolkappiyam (a Tamil grammar) by Tolkappiyar survives from the second Sangam.
Statements 3 is not correct
• Silappadikaram was written by Ilango Adigal, not Sittalai Sattanar.
• However, the text does indeed provide valuable information about Sangam polity, society, culture, and
values.
• It is one of the five great epics of Tamil literature and narrates the story of Kannagi and her husband
Kovalan.
• It offers rich descriptions of the cities of Puhar (Kaveripattinam), Madurai, and Vanji, giving insights into
urban life, trade, and governance of the time

questions.question:
Consider the following statements with respect to Sangam Age:
1. Narrative texts called Kilkanakku consist of works on heroic poetry.
2. Didactic texts called Melkannaku consist of famous works on ethics.
Which of the statement(s) given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Sangam literature can be divided into two groups: narrative and didactic.
• Poems within the Sangam age were based on two broader themes of ‘akam’ (love) and ‘puram’ (mostly
based on love but also included public poetry such as poems on good and bad, community and
kingdom).
• A remarkable feature of Sangam literature is its vivid portrayal of the contemporary society and culture
of Tamilakam and its peaceful and harmonious interactions with the northern (Aryan) culture.
Statement 1 is not correct
• The narrative works are called Melkannakku (18 major works consisting of eight anthologies and ten
idylls).
• They are considered heroic works of poetry in which heroes are glorified and perpetual wars and cattle
raids are frequently mentioned.
Statement 2 is incorrect
• The didactic works are called Kilkanakku (18 Minor works).
• The texts prescribe a code of conduct not only for the king and his court but also for various social
groups and occupations.
• Few Tamil didactic works are:
 Tiruvalluvar’s Thirukkural was a famous work on ethics, philosophy, polity and love. It is considered
as the fifth Veda of Tamil Nadu.
 Silappadikaram by Ilango Adigal is considered the brightest gem of early Tamil Literature which
deals with the love story of Kovalan, who prefers a courtesan, Madhavi of Kaveripattinam to his
noble wedded wife, Kannagi.
 Manimekalai by Satanar, is a sequel to Silappadikaram and is considered ‘The Odyssey of Tamil
poetry,’ which deals with the adventures of the daughter born to Kovalan and Madhavi, and her
subsequent conversion to Buddhism.

questions.question:
Consider the following personalities of Gupta Empire:
1. Charaka
2. Panini
3. Amarasimha
4. Shanku
5. Varahamihira
6. Dhanvantri
7. Kahapanaka
8. Vetala Bhatta
How many of the above personalities were part of Navaratnas of Chandragupta II?
questions.explanation:
Option 1 is not correct
• Charaka, an eminent ancient Indian physician, is celebrated as one of the principal contributors to
Ayurveda, the traditional system of medicine in India.
• He lived in the court of the Kushan ruler, Kanishka.
• Charaka was believed to have lived in the 1st-2nd century CE.
• His contributions are primarily recorded in the ‘Charaka Samhita,’ one of the foundational texts of Ayurveda.
• The ‘Charaka Samhita’ is a comprehensive text on ancient Indian medicine, focusing on internal medicine
(Kaya Chikitsa).
• He introduced concepts such as ‘Tridosha’ (Vata, Pitta, and Kapha) which are central to Ayurvedic medicine.
Option 2 is not correct
• Panini, the ancient Sanskrit grammarian, is not definitively known to have lived in any particular court.
• There is no historical evidence explicitly placing him in the court of any specific king or ruler.
• Panini was estimated to have lived around the 5th century BCE, and his work, ‘Ashtadhyayi,’ is a foundational text in the study of Sanskrit grammar.
• Unlike other historical figures whose associations with royal courts are well-documented, Panini's life
details remain largely obscured, and his work is celebrated more for its academic and linguistic significance rather than any direct association with royal patronage.
Option 3 is correct
• Amarasimha, one of the most renowned scholars in ancient India, is often associated with the legendary
navaratnas or nine gems in the court of King Vikramaditya or Chandragupta II.
• Amarasimha is believed to have flourished around the 4th to 5th century CE.
• Amarasimha is most famous for his work ‘Amarakosha’ which is a lexicon of Sanskrit words.
Option 4 is correct
• Shanku: An architect who wrote the Shilpashastra.
Option 5 is correct
• Varahamihira, one of the most illustrious scholars of ancient India, is renowned for his significant contributions to astronomy, astrology, and other scientific disciplines.
• He was one of the nine gems (navaratnas) in the court of King Vikramaditya.
• Major Works:
❖ Brihat Samhita
❖ Pancha Siddhantika
❖ Brihat Jataka
Option 6 is correct
• Dhanvantri, physician who is considered as the father of Ayurveda belonged to Chandragupta II’s
court.
• His famous books are ‘Roga Nidan’ and ‘Vaidya Chintamani.’
Option 7 is correct
• Kahapanaka is one of the navaratnas of the Guptan empire.
• He was an astrologer who wrote the Jyothisyashastra.
Option 8 is correct
• Vetala Bhatta is a magician who wrote ‘Mantrashastra.’
• He belonged to Chandragupta II’s court.

questions.question:
With reference to Sangam Councils, consider the following pairs:
 Sangam Council Place
1. First Sangam Kapadapuram
2. Second Sangam Madurai
3. Third Sangam Thenmadurai
How many of the above pair(s) is/are not correctly matched?
questions.explanation:
The Sangam councils, or assemblies, were significant gatherings of Tamil poets and scholars in ancient
south India, where literary works were composed and reviewed.
Pair 1 is not correct
• The first Sangam (Mudal Sangam) is traditionally believed to have taken place around 3000 BCE, although exact dates are debated and mostly based on legends.
• The first Sangam was said to be patronised by the Pandya kings, who were known for their support of
arts and literature.
• The ruler at the time was likely a legendary Pandya king named Maindan or Kaysina Valudi.
• According to tradition, the first sangam took place in Thenmadurai (Southern Madurai), which is believed to have been submerged under the sea.
• The first Sangam is believed to have produced a vast body of literature, though none of its works have
survived to the present day.
• The Sangam poets composed classical Tamil literature, including poetry, grammar, and other scholarly
works.
• Agastya, a revered sage in Tamil tradition, is often associated with the first Sangam as its presiding
figure.
Pair 2 is not correct
• The second Sangam, like the first Sangam, is an important part of Tamil literary history and tradition.
• The second Sangam (Idai Sangam) is traditionally believed to have taken place around 3000-1500 BCE,
though these dates are based on legends and lack concrete archaeological evidence.
• It was held in the city of Kapadapuram, which was a prominent cultural and scholarly centre in ancient
Tamil Nadu.
• The second Sangam was also patronised by the Pandya kings.
• The ruler during this period is said to be a Pandya king named Vendan, though historical details are
largely mythical.
• The second Sangam is credited with producing a significant body of Tamil literature, although much of it
has not survived to the present day.
